comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Glencairn House, County Dublin A neighbour of mine, the British Ambassador, lives in here. The Dublin Transport authorities have built a light rail line right past this gate and a station called Glencairn is to open outside it in a few months. From - www.geograph.ie/photo/1848267

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: FUNERAL OF MR. CROKER: - The funeral of Mr. Richard Croker took place yesterday [May 5, 1922], when the body was buried in the grounds of Glencairn House, Mr. Croker's residence in South County, Dublin. After a Requiem Mass in the private oratory, the burial service was conducted by the Right Rev. Dr. W. J. Miller, Roman Catholic Bishop of Eumenia. The body was clothed in evening dress, and before the coffin was closed Mrs. Croker desired the mourners to look at her husband's face for the last time. The coffin was covered with a pall made of natural violets and evergreen. The pall-bearers were Mr. Arthur Griffith, President of Dail Eireann, the Lord Mayor of Dublin, Mr. A. H. Flauley, of Chicago, Mr. Oliver Gogarty, Alderman Macdonagh, and Mr. J. E. Tierney. Mr. Michael Collins, Chairman of the Provisional Government, was represented by Mr. Kevin O'Shiel From - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glencairn_House

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Ricard Croker married Beulah Benson Edmondson (1884–1957[4]) in 1914 when he was 71 years old.[5] He died in 1922 in Ireland [6] leaving a fortune estimated to $3–5 millions to his second wife, disinheriting the children.[7] This resulted in a celebrated lawsuit in which the children unsuccessfully claimed that their father's second marriage was invalid for bigamy, in that their stepmother was at the relevant time married to another man. They were, however, unable to produce any credible evidence that the gentleman existed. From - en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Croker

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
From [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8623220@N02] Photostream

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6482033205/]

Irish-born Tammany Hall boss Richard Eyre Croker (1843-1922) was 71 in 1914, when he married Beulah Benton (or Benson) Edmonson (or Edmondson) (1884-1957), who was 1/16 Cherokee and an alumna of the Cherokee National Female Seminary

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/6482032947/in/photostream/]

With Nathan Strauss - owner of Macys New York

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Croker was a freeman of Dublin and won the English Derby with his horse Orby. Orby (1904–1918) was an Anglo-Irish Thoroughbred racehorse and sire. In a racing career which lasted from 1906 to 1907 he ran seven times and won four races. In 1907 he became the first Irish-trained horse, and the third owned by an American, to win the Epsom Derby. In the same year, he became the first horse to complete the Epsom Derby-Irish Derby double, but his racing career was ended by training problems after one further race. He went on to become a successful stallion en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orby_(horse)

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content:
Glencairn WAS the residence of the British Ambassador in Ireland.  Just outside the gates in 1976 the then ambassador Sir Christopher Ewart-Biggs was assassinated by the Provisional IRA when a massive landmine exploded under his car killing him and a secretary.
The Ambassador moved from there in the late '90's to a pad near Marley Park.
I never knew the Boss Croker connection and this shot has really opened up a whole new line of information.  Well done Carol, you chose well after being defeated by the Museum crowd yesterday!!!!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] I think it is still the Ambassadors residence - never actually moved to Marley. Here is a report from a garden party there in 2011. www.nickysragtales.com/tag/british-ambassador-to-ireland/

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The DIA states that the house was remodelled in 1904-5 for Croker, and was formerly the house of Judge James Murphy.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Croker earned the undying wrath of Mark Twain who in a mock eulogy to the Irish emmigrant got his facts wrong, but maybe not the tone when he said “Yes, farewell to Croker forever, the Baron of Wantage, the last, and I dare say the least desirable, addition to English nobility.” In his autobiography, Twain didn’t mince his words about Croker describing him as an “all-round blatherskite and chief pillager of the municipal till.” todayinirishhistory.com/tag/tammany-boss-richard-croker/

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
blath·er·skite  
/ˈblaT͟Hərˌskīt/
Noun
A person who talks at great length without making much sense.
Foolish talk; nonsense: "politicians get away all the time with their blatherskite".
Synonyms
bletherskate - gabber - babbler - magpie

comment._content: Bula (Beulah?) Benton Edmunson died in 1957 in Palm Beach. The house has been the British Ambassador's Residence "since the 1950s" according to wikipedia. Did she keep the house on Murphystown Road for those 30 years?

comment._content: She has a resemblance to the late Margaret Hamilton. Who was an American actress of some acclaim!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: Right, earliest possible date for this one is November 1921. The Nenagh Guardian of Saturday, 6 May 1922 says "Mr Croker and Mrs Croker returned to Ireland in November last from the United States where they had been for their usual annual visit." Obvious from the article that they hadn't been back to the States before Mr Croker died.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: He was the first person to pay $5000 for a bulldog... She is his second wife. He disinherited his children, and left 3 to 5 million bucks to her... "He is the youngest old man imaginable", per the New York Times in 1919. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-07-27/ed-...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Oh, she befriended him and married him within a few weeks of the first wife's death. She was supposed to be a Native American princess, but was Jewish... They talk about the scandal/lawsuit here...http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1919-07-16/ed-1/seq-1/ The newspaper has a picture of Beulah as an Indian princess (we call them Native Americans now). Her name seems to be Beulah, not Bula.

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: Here's the details of the will chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1922-07-09/ed-.... So apparently she was a gold-digging "princess" who knew a good thing when she saw it, married the old guy (a few weeks after wife #1 dies) and lived off his fortune, letting three of his kids suffer, except for one daughter Florence Morris who got 50 thousand dollars from her father. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1922-07-29/ed-... Florence Morris Croker loved her father dearly and didn't sue the estate. query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=F50D13F73C5D1A... Wow, this lawsuit was still underway in 1931 news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1964&dat=19310226&...
